title: Lone Cone (Colorado)
text:
Lone Cone is a <a href="Topographic%20prominence">prominent</a> <a href="mountain">mountain</a> <a href="summit">summit</a> at the western end of the <a href="San%20Miguel%20Mountains">San Miguel Mountains</a> range of the <a href="Rocky%20Mountains">Rocky Mountains</a> of <a href="North%20America">North America</a>. The peak is located west by south (<a href="Absolute%20bearing">bearing</a> 262°) of the <a href="Telluride%2C%20Colorado">Town of Telluride</a>, <a href="Colorado">Colorado</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, on the <a href="drainage%20divide">drainage divide</a> separating <a href="San%20Juan%20National%20Forest">San Juan National Forest</a> and <a href="Dolores%20County%2C%20Colorado">Dolores County</a> from <a href="Uncompahgre%20National%20Forest">Uncompahgre National Forest</a> and <a href="San%20Miguel%20County%2C%20Colorado">San Miguel County</a>.
Geology.
The mountain, a <a href="laccolith">laccolith</a>, is between 20 and 40 million years old and is the westernmost of over a dozen laccoliths that are the same age as rocks in the <a href="San%20Juan%20volcanic%20field">San Juan volcanic field</a>.
